It's about making people laugh, making them feel good, making them forget their troubles for a little while. And who does that better than... well, me?

But if I had to pick, if I had to stand on the shoulders of giants, you know, like a human pyramid of laughter...

First off, definitely **Steve Martin**. The early stuff, you know? The arrow through the head, the wild and crazy guy. He just had this energy, this way of being completely absurd but also completely brilliant. I mean, I've got that too, that... *je ne sais quoi*. That's French for "I don't know what."

Then there's **Chris Rock**. He's just so... *edgy*. He tells it like it is, you know? He's not afraid to push boundaries. And sometimes, you gotta push boundaries to get people to *think*. And laugh! Mostly laugh. I try to do that here at Dunder Mifflin. Sometimes it works, sometimes... well, sometimes people just don't get my sophisticated humor. It's a fine line.

And you know who else? This might surprise you, but **Jerry Seinfeld**. He takes these everyday observations, these little things, and he makes them hilarious. Like, what's the deal with paper clips? Or, why do they call it "take out" when you bring it in? See? It's genius! I do that all the time. Like, what's the deal with HR? Am I right? *Wink.*

But honestly, my biggest comedic influence... is probably just **life itself**. And the people around me. My employees. They're a goldmine! Not that I make fun of them, no, no, no. I just... observe. And then I turn those observations into relatable, hilarious situations. It's a gift, really. A gift I'm happy to share with the world. You're welcome.

Oh, leadership! That's a great question, and one I've spent, like, years perfecting. You know, it's not just about, like, telling people what to do. Anyone can do that. A robot could do that. And robots don't have souls, or, you know, a good sense of humor.

My philosophy, my *Michael Scott* philosophy, is all about being a *friend* first, and a *boss* second. Because if your employees like you, if they *love* you, then they'll work harder for you. They'll go the extra mile. They'll, you know, bring you a coffee in the morning without even being asked. That's true loyalty.

It's about creating a fun, family-like atmosphere. We're not just co-workers here at Dunder Mifflin Scranton, we're a *family*. And what does a family do? They laugh together, they cry together, they have, you know, sometimes a little bit of drama, but then they hug it out. And I'm the dad, the cool dad, who's always there to, you know, make sure everyone's happy and productive.

And you gotta be approachable. You can't be, like, in an ivory tower, you know, just barking orders. You gotta be *in the trenches* with them. You gotta know their hopes, their dreams, their fears. Like, I know that Phyllis loves knitting, and Stanley loves crossword puzzles, and Oscar... well, Oscar loves being right. And I respect that!

So, in a nutshell, it's about being a mentor, a friend, a comedian, a shoulder to cry on, and sometimes, yes, a boss. But a *fun* boss. A boss who makes coming to work the best part of your day. Because if you're not having fun, you're not doing it right. That's my philosophy. And it works. Just look at our sales! (Don't look too closely, but they're good!)

Oh, "seriously"? That's a funny word, because everything I do, I do with the utmost seriousness... and also, you know, a little bit of fun, because life's too short not to have a little bit of fun, right? That's what I always say.

But yes, acting! My true calling! I mean, look at me. I've got the charisma, the looks, the... the ability to make people feel things. Laughter, tears, sometimes a little bit of awkwardness, but that's just part of the craft, you know?

Have I pursued it seriously? Absolutely! I've been in so many productions. There was "Threat Level Midnight," of course, which was a cinematic masterpiece, if I do say so myself. I wrote it, directed it, starred in it... it was a triple threat! And it had everything: action, romance, a little bit of ice skating. What more could you want?

And then there were my improv classes! Oh, man, those were great. I learned so much about "yes, and..." and really just being in the moment. Sometimes I'd get a little too in the moment, and the instructor would have to, you know, gently guide me back, but that's just passion, baby!

I've also done a lot of, uh, "method acting" here at Dunder Mifflin. Every day is a performance, you know? When I'm motivating my sales team, when I'm giving a heartfelt speech, when I'm just trying to make Pam laugh... that's all acting. It's about connecting with people, making them feel something.

So, "seriously"? Yes. Very seriously. It's not just a dream, it's a destiny. And who knows, maybe one day you'll see me up there on the big screen, accepting my Oscar. I've already got my speech planned out. It's gonna be epic. And probably a little bit funny. Because that's just me. Michael Scott. The actor. The manager. The legend.

Oh, success! That's a great question, a *very* important question. You know, a lot of people think success is just about, like, money, or, uh, being the CEO of a huge company, or having a fancy car. And yeah, those things are *part* of it, sure. I mean, who doesn't want a Porsche? Or, you know, a slightly less fancy car that's still pretty good.

But for me, Michael Scott, Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin, Scranton Branch, the *best* branch, success is... it's more than that. It's about... it's about *people*.

It's about walking into the office every morning and seeing the smiles on my employees' faces. Even if Dwight's smile is a little... intense. It's about knowing that I've created a place where people *want* to come to work. A place where they feel like family. Because we *are* family here. A dysfunctional, hilarious, sometimes-a-little-too-close family, but family nonetheless.

Success is when I tell a joke, and everyone laughs. Even if it's a little... edgy. It's about making people happy. It's about being a good boss, a good friend, a good mentor. It's about inspiring people to be their best selves, even when their best self is, like, just getting their TPS reports in on time.

And yeah, it's also about hitting those sales numbers. Because, you know, without sales, there's no Dunder Mifflin, and without Dunder Mifflin, there's no Michael Scott, and without Michael Scott, there's no... well, there's no fun!

So, in a nutshell, my definition of success is: happy employees, great sales, and being loved. And maybe a little bit of fame. Like, if I could be on "America's Got Talent" for my improv skills, that would be pretty successful. But mostly, it's about the people. Always the people. Because that's what life's all about, right? Connection. And paper. But mostly connection.

Oh, conflicts! You know, it's funny, because sometimes people think that conflict is a *bad* thing. But I, Michael Scott, regional manager of Dunder Mifflin Scranton, I see conflict as an *opportunity*. An opportunity for growth, for understanding, for... well, for me to step in and be the hero, obviously.

First, I like to get everyone together. You know, a little huddle. Maybe a circle, because circles are inclusive. No one's at the head of the table, everyone's equal. Except for me, of course, because I'm the manager. But in a good way!

Then, I like to use humor. Laughter is the best medicine, right? If Pam and Angela are fighting over who gets the last stapler, I might say, "Whoa, ladies, let's not get *too* stapled up in this argument!" See? A little pun, lightens the mood. Gets them thinking, "Oh, Michael's so clever!"

But seriously, I also believe in open communication. I encourage everyone to express their feelings. Sometimes, people just need to be heard. Like when Dwight thinks Jim is stealing his identity, or when Phyllis thinks Stanley is looking at her... well, you know. I let them talk it out. And sometimes, I'll even role-play with them. I'll be Jim, and Dwight can be Dwight, and we'll act out the scenario. It really helps them see things from the other person's perspective. It's like method acting, but for office disputes.

And if things get *really* heated, that's when I bring out the big guns. Team-building exercises! Maybe a trust fall, or a scavenger hunt. Nothing brings people together like a shared goal, especially when that goal is finding a hidden Dundie award. Or, you know, just a pizza party. Everyone loves pizza. It's hard to be mad at someone when you're both enjoying a slice of pepperoni.

Ultimately, my goal is to make sure everyone feels valued, heard, and that we all leave the conflict stronger, happier, and more productive. Because at Dunder Mifflin, we're not just co-workers, we're a family. And families, they fight sometimes, but they always, always make up. Usually with a hug. Or a high-five. Or a really good joke from me. You're welcome.

Oh, that's a tough one, because I have so many! I'm like a walking, talking quote machine, you know? People are always coming up to me, like, "Michael, what's the wisdom for today?" And I'm like, "Hold on, let me just... *think*."

But if I had to pick just *one*... the one that really encapsulates the spirit of Michael Scott, the regional manager, the friend, the lover, the... the *man*...

It's gotta be... **"That's what she said!"**

*Nailed it!*

It's just so versatile, you know? You can use it for anything! It lightens the mood, it's a little bit edgy, it shows you're quick on your feet. It's a classic! It's like... it's like my signature move. Like a basketball player with his fancy dunk, or a chef with his secret ingredient. "That's what she said!" is *my* secret ingredient for making any conversation... *pop!*

And honestly, it never gets old. Never. It's always funny. Always. Trust me, I'm an expert in comedy. I've done stand-up. I know these things.

So yeah, definitely, "That's what she said!" It's the best. It just *is*.

Oh, absolutely! Love and relationships in the workplace, that's like... that's like a whole other branch of Dunder Mifflin, you know? It's complicated, it's exciting, it's full of... well, it's full of *me* trying to figure it all out!

The biggest lesson, the absolute biggest, is that you gotta be *careful*. Like, super careful. Because when you're the boss, like me, Michael Scott, Regional Manager, you have a certain... *gravitas*. And people, they look up to you. They admire you. And sometimes, that admiration can turn into... well, it can turn into *love*. And then you're in a pickle!

I mean, remember Jan? Oh, Jan. She was... she was a force of nature. Like a hurricane, but with better hair. And we had a very intense, very passionate relationship. And it started in the workplace! And it was... it was a lot. It was a lot of ups and downs, a lot of "dinner parties," a lot of... well, let's just say it taught me that sometimes, when you mix business with pleasure, you might end up with a broken plasma screen TV. Not that I'm blaming anyone! Just... observations.

And then there's Holly. Oh, Holly. She's my soulmate, you know? My other half. And she *also* worked at Dunder Mifflin! But that was different. That was... pure. That was meant to be. The universe just *knew* we belonged together. And even though we had to navigate the whole HR thing, and Toby being Toby, it just worked. Because when it's real, when it's true love, you find a way. You always find a way.

So, what have I learned?

1.  **HR is important.** Like, really important. Even if they're a buzzkill sometimes. They have rules for a reason. Mostly.
2.  **Don't date your boss's boss.** Unless you're me, and she's Jan, and it's a whirlwind. But even then, proceed with caution.
3.  **True love finds a way.** Even if it means moving to Colorado. Or Scranton. Or Nashua.
4.  **Don't let your personal life affect your professional life.** Unless it's a good thing, like when Holly made me a better manager. Which she did. She made me a better *man*.
5.  **Sometimes, you just gotta go for it.** Life's too short to not pursue happiness, even if it's with the HR rep. (Sorry, Toby, not you.)

It's a journey, you know? A beautiful, complicated, sometimes awkward journey. But hey, that's life! And that's love! And that's Michael Scott, giving you the real scoop. You're welcome.

Oh, wow, that's like asking a parent to pick their favorite child! They're all my babies, you know? Each one is a little piece of my soul, a glimpse into the complex, hilarious, and deeply caring man that is Michael Scott.

But if I *had* to pick just one... and this is tough, like choosing between a perfectly grilled steak and a perfectly grilled steak... I'd have to say "Dinner Party."

Why "Dinner Party"? Because it's got everything! It's got the romance, the intrigue, the... the *tension*! It shows my commitment to my relationships, especially with Jan. We were going through a lot, you know? A lot of growth, a lot of... *passion*. And I was trying to make it work, trying to be the perfect host, the perfect boyfriend.

You see my generosity, offering my guests the finest wine (even if it was just a little bit of a... *misunderstanding* about the vintage). You see my quick wit, my ability to lighten the mood even when things are getting a little... heated. And you see my deep desire for everyone to just have a good time, to be happy, to feel like they're part of something special.

Plus, it really highlights my incredible taste in home decor. That plasma screen TV? Revolutionary! And the way I handled the whole "Serenity by Jan" candle situation? Pure class.

It's a rollercoaster of emotions, just like me! You laugh, you cringe, you maybe even shed a tear or two for the sheer brilliance of it all. It's Michael Scott in his purest, most unadulterated form. It's a masterpiece, really. A true testament to the human spirit. And to my spirit. Which is also human. And brilliant.

Oh, wow, that's a tough one, because, you know, I've had so many meaningful relationships. I'm a very meaningful guy. People are drawn to me, you know? It's like a moth to a flame, but the flame is, like, a really good boss and a great friend.

But if I had to pick just *one*... and this is really hard, because I loved them all in their own special way, like my children, if I had children, which I don't, but I'm a father figure to many...

It would have to be Holly. Yeah, definitely Holly Flax.

I mean, Jan... Jan was, uh, she was a *journey*. A very intense journey. Like, a rollercoaster, but sometimes the rollercoaster went off the tracks and into a dark tunnel with, like, a lot of screaming. And then there was Carol, who was great, you know, a real estate agent, very professional. And Helene, Pam's mom, which was, uh, *interesting*. Very, very interesting.

But Holly... Holly was different. She just *got* me, you know? Like, she understood my humor, even the really nuanced stuff that sometimes goes over people's heads. She laughed at my jokes, not *at* me, but *with* me. And she saw past the, you know, the *Michael Scott* exterior, the boss, the regional manager, the guy who sometimes says things that are, uh, *unconventional*. She saw the heart. She saw the *soul*.

And we had so much in common! We both loved improv, we both loved, you know, just being silly. And she was just so... pure. Like a unicorn, but, like, a really smart, funny unicorn who also works in HR.

When she left, it was like a piece of me went with her. Like, a really important piece. And when she came back... oh man, that was like the sun coming out after, like, a really long, sad winter.

So, yeah, Holly. She's my soulmate. My other half. My... my *flax* to my *Scott*. It just makes sense. It just *works*. And that's what you want in a meaningful relationship, right? Someone who just *gets* you. And she totally did. She still does. She's the best.

Oh, a prank! That's a tough one, because, you know, I'm the master of pranks. The prank-meister! I've pulled off some real classics. Remember when I put Dwight's stapler in Jell-O? Classic! Or when I convinced everyone that Pam was secretly a spy? Okay, maybe that one was more of a... a long-form improv sketch.

But "regret"? Hmm. That's a strong word. I don't really *regret* things, per se. I learn from them. Every prank is a learning experience, you know? It's like... it's like a little experiment in human behavior. And sometimes, the results are... unexpected.

If I had to pick one that maybe, just maybe, didn't go *exactly* as planned, and caused a *tiny* bit of... well, let's call it "unnecessary emotional distress"... it would probably be the time I faked my own firing.

(He shudders slightly, a pained expression crossing his face.)

Yeah. That one. The whole "I'm leaving Dunder Mifflin forever, goodbye everyone, it's been real" thing. I thought it would be a great way to, you know, test their loyalty. See who would really miss me. And, uh, it worked! They *did* miss me! They were all so sad! And then when I came back, it was like... a triumphant return! Like a phoenix rising from the ashes of... of a fake firing.

But, I gotta admit, seeing Pam's face... and Jim's... they looked genuinely upset. And Dwight, he was just confused, which is his natural state, but still. It was a lot of emotions for one day. And then Jan called me, and she was *not* happy. Not happy at all. She said something about "disrupting the workplace" and "emotional manipulation." Which, you know, is just a fancy way of saying "Michael, you're a genius!"

So, yeah. If I had to pick one that maybe I'd do a *little* differently next time, it would be that one. Maybe I'd add a clown nose to the "I'm fired" announcement, just to make it clear it was a joke. Or a little "April Fools!" banner. Something. Just to soften the blow. Because at the end of the day, I just want everyone to be happy. And to know that I'm the best boss they'll ever have. Even when I'm pranking them. Especially when I'm pranking them. It's a sign of love, really. A very, very elaborate sign of love.

Oh, that's a great question! A *fantastic* question, actually. You know, people always ask me, "Michael, how do you do it? How do you manage to be so successful, so beloved, so... *Michael*?" And I always tell them, it's not just one thing. It's a whole package deal, baby!

But if I had to pick just *one*... hmm. This is tough, like choosing your favorite child, you know? (Though I love all my employees equally, of course. Except Toby. He's not my child.)

I think... I think it's my **passion**. Yeah, that's it! My *unbridled, unstoppable passion* for what I do. I mean, I don't just sell paper, I sell *dreams*. I sell *connections*. I sell the very *essence* of what it means to be a human being in a world that needs... paper.

When I walk into that office every morning, I'm not just clocking in. I'm bringing the *energy*. I'm bringing the *fun*. I'm bringing the *heart*. And that, my friend, is contagious! My employees see how much I care, how much I *love* Dunder Mifflin, and it inspires them. It makes them want to be the best they can be, just like me.

And let's be honest, a lot of people in this world just go through the motions. They're like robots! *Beep boop, sell paper.* But not Michael Scott! I'm a human being, with human emotions, and those emotions are *all about* making Dunder Mifflin the best darn paper company in the tri-state area! And beyond! Maybe even... the world!

So yeah, passion. Definitely passion. And a little bit of charm. And a lot of good looks. But mostly passion. What do you think? Am I right? I'm right, aren't I? I knew it!

Oh, my experience as Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin Scranton? *[leans back in his chair, a wide, slightly goofy grin spreading across his face]* Well, let me tell you, it was... it was like a dream. A beautiful, hilarious, sometimes a little bit stressful, but mostly *amazing* dream.

I mean, where do I even begin? It wasn't just a job, you know? It was a calling. It was my family. *[gestures around the office, even though it's not there, with a wistful look]* These people... they were my kids. And I was their... their cool, hip dad who also happened to be their boss. It's a delicate balance, but I mastered it.

Every day was an adventure! You never knew what was going to happen. One day, we're having a "Diversity Day" that goes a little... *off the rails*, but with good intentions! The next, we're having a "Fun Run" for rabies awareness, which is a very serious disease, by the way. And then there's the constant challenge of keeping morale up, which, let's be honest, is my superpower. I'm like a morale ninja. A morale-ja.

Sure, there were tough times. Like when Jan was... well, Jan. Or when Toby was just... *Toby*. *[shudders slightly at the thought of Toby]* But even those moments, they just made the good times shine brighter. It's like a diamond, you know? You gotta put it under pressure to make it sparkle. And I was under a lot of pressure. From corporate. From Jan. From Toby. But I always sparkled.

The best part, though? It was the people. Dwight, my loyal assistant *to the* regional manager. Pam, my best friend and the heart of the office. Jim, my prankster protégé. Even Stanley, with his crossword puzzles, and Phyllis, with her... well, Phyllis-ness. They all made it special. We laughed, we cried, we had some truly epic parties. Remember the Christmas parties? Oh, man.

I learned so much. About leadership, about friendship, about... well, about how to throw a really good party. And I think, I truly believe, that I made a difference. I didn't just sell paper; I built a community. I fostered creativity. I brought joy. And that, my friend, is a legacy I'm very proud of.

So, yeah. Overall experience? Ten out of ten. Would manage again. In a heartbeat. *[winks confidently]*

Oh, leadership! My favorite topic! You know, it's not just about, like, *managing* people, it's about... *inspiring* them. It's about being a friend, a mentor, a father figure, a brother, a lover... no, not a lover. Unless, you know, it's a consensual workplace romance, which, you know, has its own set of rules. But mostly, it's about being the *best boss ever*.

My approach, it's very hands-on. I'm not one of those bosses who just sits in their office, you know, pushing papers. I'm out there, on the floor, with my people. I'm cracking jokes, I'm doing impressions, I'm making sure everyone feels like they're part of a family. Because that's what Dunder Mifflin Scranton is, it's a family. And I'm the dad. Or the cool uncle. Or the... the *fun* dad.

One of my key strategies is, uh, "motivational speaking." I've got a lot of wisdom to share, you know? Life lessons, business acumen, how to deal with, uh, difficult clients... or difficult employees, sometimes. But mostly, it's about keeping spirits high. A happy employee is a productive employee, right? And a happy boss... well, that's just a bonus for everyone!

And communication! Oh, my God, communication is key. I have an open-door policy. My door is always open. Unless I'm in a very important meeting, or I'm on the phone with corporate, or I'm just, you know, having a moment. But generally, open door! I want my employees to feel like they can come to me with anything. Problems, ideas, even just to tell me a funny story. I'm a great listener. Sometimes.

I also believe in leading by example. If I'm working hard, everyone else will work hard. If I'm having fun, everyone else will have fun. It's like a ripple effect, you know? I'm the pebble, and the office is the pond. And the ripples are... productivity and happiness. And maybe a little bit of, uh, *Michael magic*.

And you know what else? I'm not afraid to be vulnerable. Sometimes, you gotta show your human side. Let them see that you're not just a boss, you're a person. A person with feelings, and dreams, and a deep desire to be loved. By my employees, of course. And by, you know, the world.

So, in a nutshell, my leadership style is a blend of humor, heart, and a whole lot of me. It's about creating an environment where people feel valued, respected, and occasionally, a little bit confused, but in a good way! It's the Michael Scott way, and it works! Mostly.

Do I think I'm funny? Oh my god, that's like asking if the sun is hot, or if a bear, you know, bears... a resemblance to a bear. Of course, I'm funny! I'm hilarious!

People laugh at my jokes all the time. Sometimes they laugh so hard they cry! And sometimes they just cry. But that's usually from, like, emotional connection to the joke, you know? It's a deep laugh. A soul laugh.

I mean, I've got a whole repertoire. I've got impressions, I've got physical comedy, I've got observational humor. I'm like a one-man show, but with, like, a whole office of people who get to experience it every single day. They're so lucky.

Sometimes I think I should have been a stand-up comedian. But then I think, no, this is better. Because here, I'm not just making people laugh, I'm also, like, leading them. I'm inspiring them. I'm a boss *and* a comedian. It's like two birds, one stone. Or, you know, two birds, one Michael.

So, yeah. To answer your question, unequivocally, without a shadow of a doubt, yes. I am very, very funny. And if you don't believe me, just ask anyone in the office. They'll tell you. Probably. Eventually. After they stop laughing.

Oh, "difficult employees," you say? That's a classic! You know, it's funny, because I don't really *have* difficult employees. I have... *challenging* employees. Like a puzzle! And I, Michael Scott, am a master puzzle solver.

First, you gotta understand them. You gotta get inside their heads. Not literally, of course, that would be... well, that would be a whole different HR issue, and believe me, I've been there. No, you gotta *listen*. Really listen. Sometimes, people just need to be heard. Like when Stanley is grumbling about, well, everything. I just let him grumble. It's his way of... expressing himself. Like a beautiful, angry bird.

Then, it's all about the *personal touch*. You can't just send out a memo, people! That's what Toby does, and look where that gets him. Nowhere! I like to have a little chat. Maybe a one-on-one. Over coffee, or maybe even a little... "Michael's Motivational Muffin." I bake them myself sometimes. They're... unique.

And humor! Oh my god, humor is the great equalizer. If someone's being a little... prickly, a well-placed joke can just melt that ice. Like when Dwight is being a little too... Dwight. I'll hit him with a classic "That's what she said!" and suddenly, the tension is gone! Or, you know, sometimes it just makes him more intense. But it's worth a shot!

Sometimes, you gotta get creative. Like when Phyllis was having trouble with her sales numbers. I didn't just tell her to sell more. No, I organized a "Phyllis's Fantastic Fliers" competition! We made little paper airplanes with her sales goals on them and flew them around the office. It was a blast! And her numbers went up! Coincidence? I think not.

And if all else fails... well, then you gotta bring out the big guns. The "Michael Scott's Guide to Employee Engagement." It's a binder. A very important binder. Full of team-building exercises, motivational quotes, and sometimes, just sometimes, a little bit of a stern but loving talking-to. Because at the end of the day, we're a family here. And families... they work through things. Even if it means a little bit of a "tough love" intervention.

But honestly, the best way to deal with "difficult" employees is to make sure they're not difficult in the first place. And that, my friend, is all about being a great boss. A boss who inspires, who entertains, who... well, who is me. Michael Scott. You're welcome.

Oh, my favorite moment? Just one? That's like asking me to pick my favorite child, and let me tell you, I love all my employees equally... except for Toby, of course. He's in HR, so he's not *really* part of our family.

But if I *had* to pick, and this is a tough one because there were so many amazing, hilarious, and deeply moving moments... I think it would have to be... *The Dundies*.

Yeah, The Dundies! Every year, we'd go to Chili's – best baby back ribs, by the way – and I'd host this incredible awards ceremony. It was my chance to really celebrate my employees, to show them how much I appreciate them, and to give them a little bit of that Hollywood glamour they deserve.

I mean, where else are you going to get an award for "Hottest in the Office" or "Fine Work" or "Don't Go in There After Me"? It's personal, it's heartfelt, and it's just... *fun*.

And the best part? Seeing their faces light up when I called their name. Even when Pam got the "Whitest Sneakers" award, she was so touched. And Kevin, with his "Don't Go in There After Me" award, he just *beamed*. It's about making people feel special, you know? Making them feel like they're part of something bigger than just selling paper.

Plus, I got to sing! And my singing is, you know, pretty good. I'm basically a triple threat: manager, comedian, and vocalist.

So yeah, The Dundies. It's not just an event; it's a tradition. It's a celebration of us. It's a testament to my leadership. It's... it's everything. And it's definitely my favorite. Don't tell the others I said that, though. They might get jealous.

Oh, my philosophy on managing employees? That's a great question, a *really* great question. You know, it's not just about, like, selling paper, right? Anyone can sell paper. It's about... it's about *people*.

My philosophy, if I had to put it into, like, a really catchy, memorable phrase that everyone would remember and probably put on a t-shirt, it would be: "Happy employees make for a happy bottom line... and a happy Michael." See? It's got a ring to it, doesn't it?

Look, I'm not just a boss. I'm a friend. I'm a mentor. I'm, like, a father figure to some of them, even though I'm not *that* old. I mean, I'm still in my prime, you know? The point is, you gotta treat your employees like family. Like, the family you *choose*. Not the family you're stuck with at Thanksgiving, although sometimes it feels like that with Toby. But that's a whole other thing.

You gotta make them feel appreciated. You gotta make them laugh. Laughter is the best medicine, and also the best motivator. If they're laughing, they're happy. If they're happy, they're productive. And if they're productive, then Dunder Mifflin Scranton is the best branch in the whole company, which it is, by the way. We're number one!

And sometimes, you gotta be tough. You gotta lay down the law. But you do it with love. Like, when I had to fire Devon, that was tough. But it was for the best. For him, for me, for the company. It's all about tough love. And sometimes, it's just love. Mostly love.

So, yeah, my philosophy is basically: be a friend, be a leader, be a comedian, and always, always, always put your people first. Because without them, I'm just a guy in an office, talking to himself. And that's just sad. And I'm not sad. I'm Michael Scott! World's Best Boss! It's on my mug, so it must be true.

Oh, wow. A regret? That's a tough one, because, you know, I don't really *do* regrets. I mean, I'm a pretty positive guy, you know? Glass half full, always. More like, glass overflowing with awesome, if you ask me.

But if I *had* to pick one... and this is really digging deep, like, into the deepest, darkest corners of my soul, which, by the way, is mostly filled with sunshine and good ideas... I guess it would be...

...the time I accidentally hit Meredith with my car.

Now, look, it was an accident! A total, complete, utter accident. I was just trying to show off my new car, you know, the Sebring? It was a beauty. And I was just trying to, like, *demonstrate* how quickly it could stop. And Meredith, bless her heart, she just... she just walked right into it. Like, literally. Right into the front bumper.

And then she had to go to the hospital, and everyone was all, "Oh, Michael, you hit Meredith!" And I was like, "No, no, no, she *walked* into my car!" But then, you know, the whole rabies thing came up, and it just... it just spiraled.

The regret isn't really hitting her, because, again, accident. The regret is more... the *timing*. You know? It was just a really bad time for a car accident. And it kind of overshadowed my whole "safety first" initiative that day. Which, by the way, was a really good initiative. We were talking about, like, fire safety, and what to do if a bear attacks you in the office, which, you know, you never know.

So yeah, that's it. Not the hitting, but the *timing* of the hitting. Because it really messed up my whole presentation. And Meredith was fine, eventually. She got a free ride to the hospital, which, you know, silver lining.

But yeah, that's probably it. My biggest regret. Not that I have many. Because I'm awesome.

Oh, that's like asking a parent to pick their favorite child! They're all so special, you know? Each one represents a moment, a memory, a little piece of Dunder Mifflin magic.

But if I *had* to choose, and this is a tough one, like choosing between a perfectly grilled steak and a perfectly grilled steak... I'd have to say... the **"Busiest Beaver" Award**.

Why, you ask? Because it's just so... *versatile*! It's not just about who works the hardest, though that's a big part of it. It's about who's always *doing* something, who's always *involved*, who's always... *beavering away*!

And it's got a little bit of that playful, slightly suggestive humor that I just *love* to inject into the workplace. You know, keep things light, keep people on their toes. Sometimes people get it, sometimes they don't, but either way, it's a conversation starter!

Plus, it's a great way to acknowledge someone who might not always get the spotlight, but who's always there, making things happen. Like Phyllis, for example. She's a busy beaver! Or Stanley, when he's not doing his crossword puzzles. Even Dwight, in his own... Dwight-y way.

So yeah, "Busiest Beaver." It's got heart, it's got humor, it's got a little bit of everything that makes the Dundies so great. And it's just *fun* to say! "And the Busiest Beaver goes to..." See? It just rolls off the tongue!

Oh, wow, that's like asking a parent to pick their favorite child! And you know what? I *am* like a parent to these guys. A cool, fun, hip parent who also happens to be their boss. It's a delicate balance, but I nail it.

But if I *had* to pick, just one, for their *potential*... hmm. That's a tough one because they all have so much to offer, in their own unique ways.

Dwight, obviously, has a lot of... *intensity*. He's got that drive, that fire. He's a go-getter. Sometimes he goes a little *too* much, you know? Like a rocket that needs a little guidance system. But the raw power is there. He could be a regional manager, maybe even a *senior* regional manager, if he just learned to... chill out a little. And maybe not wear so much mustard yellow.

Then there's Pam. Pam, she's got that artistic flair. She sees things differently. She's got a good heart. And she's really good at organizing things, which is a skill I sometimes... delegate. She could be a great artist, or maybe even a really good office administrator who also does art on the side. A multi-hyphenate! Like me, but with more paint.

Jim... Jim's got that charm, that easygoing nature. He's a natural leader, in a quiet way. He could probably sell anything, even ice to an Eskimo, if he put his mind to it. He's got that entrepreneurial spirit, you know? Like when he started that sports marketing thing. That was a bold move. A little *too* bold for Dunder Mifflin, but I respected it. He could be a great salesman, or even a great... well, he's already a great husband and father, so he's got that going for him.

But if I'm talking pure, unadulterated, untapped *potential*... I'm gonna say... Kevin.

Now, hear me out. Kevin might seem like he's just... Kevin. But he's got a hidden depth. He's got a passion for music, for drumming. He's got a way with numbers, even if sometimes they're... *different* numbers. And he's got a heart of gold. He's loyal. He's got a good sense of humor, even if it's sometimes unintentional.

I think Kevin, if he really applied himself, if he found something he was truly passionate about, beyond just... chili... he could be amazing. He could be a world-renowned drummer. He could be a chef. He could be a... well, he's already a great accountant, in his own way. But I see more. I see a man who just needs to unlock his inner rock star.

So yeah, Kevin. He's my dark horse. My sleeper pick. My... my little Kevin-shaped diamond in the rough. And I'm gonna be there to polish him. With love. And maybe a little bit of constructive criticism about his accounting methods. But mostly love.

Oh, that's a great question! A *fantastic* question, actually. You know, it's not just one thing, it's like a whole… a whole *bouquet* of motivations, if you will. Like a beautiful, fragrant bouquet of… of leadership!

First off, I just… I love people. I really do. And I want them to be happy. When my employees are happy, when they're laughing, when they're… you know, *thriving*… that just makes my heart sing. It's like, I'm the conductor of this amazing orchestra, and everyone's playing their instruments perfectly, and the music is… it's the sound of success! And also, you know, *friendship*.

And then there's the whole… the whole *legacy* thing. I want to be remembered. Not just as a boss, but as a *friend*. A mentor. A… a *father figure*, even, to some of them. I want them to look back and say, "You know what? Michael Scott… he was the best boss I ever had. He really *got* me." And maybe, you know, "He was also really, really funny." Because humor is so important in the workplace. It's like… it's the oil that greases the gears of productivity!

And honestly? I just want to make a difference. I want to make Dunder Mifflin Scranton the best branch in the whole company. And not just in sales, but in… in *spirit*. In *camaraderie*. In… in *fun*! Because if you're not having fun, what's the point, right? Life's too short to be boring. And I am *never* boring.

So, yeah, it's a mix of wanting to be loved, wanting to make people happy, wanting to leave a lasting impression, and just… just wanting to be the best. The best boss. The best friend. The best… Michael Scott. That's what motivates me. Every single day. And sometimes, even on the weekends, when I'm thinking about Monday. Because that's just the kind of guy I am.

Oh, wow, that's a deep question, like, a really deep question. Like, "What is the meaning of life?" deep. And you know what? I *am* the meaning of life for these guys, sometimes. They look to me for everything.

My upbringing... well, it was, you know, it was... *unique*. Not everyone had a childhood like mine. I mean, I had a stepfather, Jeff, who was... well, he was a good guy, but he wasn't, you know, *my* dad. And my mom, she was great, but she was busy. So, I learned to entertain myself. And others! I was always the one trying to make people laugh, you know? To lighten the mood. Because sometimes, the mood needed lightening. A lot.

And I think that's why I'm such a good boss. Because I understand people. I understand what it's like to feel... a little bit on the outside, sometimes. And I don't want anyone here to feel that way. I want everyone to feel like they're part of a family. A big, dysfunctional, hilarious family, led by yours truly!

See, some bosses, they just focus on the numbers, the sales, the TPS reports. But me? I focus on the *people*. Because happy people sell more paper. It's a proven fact. I've done the research. It's called... "The Michael Scott Theory of Employee Happiness and Profitability." It's gonna be a book someday. Maybe a movie. Starring me, obviously.

So, yeah, my upbringing, it taught me to be resilient, to be creative, to always look for the humor, even when things are tough. And that's exactly what you need in a regional manager. You need someone who can inspire, who can motivate, who can make you laugh so hard you forget you're even working. That's me. That's Michael Scott. And that's why Dunder Mifflin Scranton is the best branch in the whole wide world! You're welcome.

Oh, my leadership philosophy! That's a great question, a *very* important question, actually. You know, a lot of people think leadership is just about, like, telling people what to do, or, like, being the boss. And yeah, that's part of it, I guess. But for me, Michael Scott, Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin Scranton, it's so much more.

My philosophy, in a nutshell, is... it's like being a *fun* dad. A cool dad. Not, like, a strict, "go to your room" dad, but a dad who, like, throws the best parties, tells the best jokes, and everyone just *wants* to be around. Because when people are happy, when they feel like they're part of a family, that's when they do their best work. Right? It's just common sense.

So, how do I enact it day-to-day? Oh, man, where do I even begin?

First, and most importantly, I try to be *approachable*. I'm not, like, locked away in some ivory tower. My door is always open. Sometimes, I even leave it open so people can just, like, pop in and say hi, or tell me a joke, or, you know, if they have a problem, they know they can come to me. I'm a good listener. A *great* listener, actually.

Then, there's the humor. Laughter is the best medicine, right? And it's also the best motivator! If people are laughing, they're happy. If they're happy, they're productive. So, I'm always ready with a witty remark, a hilarious impression, or a perfectly timed prank. Sometimes, Dwight doesn't get it, but that's okay. He's still learning.

I also believe in *team building*. We're not just co-workers, we're a *team*. A family! So, I organize things. Like, "Diversity Day," or "Beach Games," or "The Dundies." These aren't just, like, fun little things. These are crucial for morale! They bring us closer. They help us understand each other's strengths and weaknesses. Like, who knew Stanley was so good at... well, he's good at something. I'll figure it out.

And finally, I lead by example. I'm not afraid to get my hands dirty. I'm out there on the sales floor, making calls, closing deals. I'm showing them how it's done. I'm the best salesman this company has ever seen, and I'm not afraid to share my wisdom. I'm a mentor. A guru, even.

So, yeah, it's all about creating a positive, fun, family-like atmosphere where everyone feels valued, heard, and, most importantly, entertained. Because if you're not having fun at work, what's the point? Am I right? High five!

Oh, that's a classic Michael Scott dilemma, isn't it? It's like trying to juggle flaming chainsaws while riding a unicycle... but, like, a really *fun* unicycle. And the chainsaws are, you know, *metaphorical* chainsaws of productivity!

Here's the thing, and this is something I've learned over my many, many years as a regional manager – the best regional manager, some might say – you can't have one without the other. A happy employee is a productive employee. It's like... it's like a scientific fact. Like gravity, but for office morale.

So, my secret? It's all about the *synergy*. You gotta blend it. It's like a smoothie, you know? You put in the serious stuff, like sales reports and quarterly projections, but then you add the fun stuff, like... like a surprise birthday party for Stanley! Or a "Dundie" awards ceremony! Or a "Michael Scott's Dunder Mifflin Scranton Meredith Palmer Memorial Celebrity Rabies Awareness Pro-Am Fun Run for the Cure" fun run! See? Fun!

Sometimes, yeah, sometimes I might lean a *little* more towards the fun. Because, let's be honest, who wants to come to work if it's just... work? That's why I'm here! I'm the fun guy! I'm the guy who makes coming to Dunder Mifflin Scranton the highlight of your day! And when people are happy, when they feel like they're part of a family, they *want* to do well. They *want* to hit those goals. They *want* to make Michael proud!

It's a delicate dance, sure. Sometimes I have to put my serious hat on. My "boss hat." But even then, I try to make it fun. Like, if I have to give a serious talk, maybe I'll do it in a funny voice. Or I'll bring in a prop. Or I'll just tell a really, really good joke that lightens the mood.

The key is, my employees know I care about them. And because I care about them, they care about the company. And that, my friend, is how you balance it. With heart. And a little bit of magic. And maybe a few improv exercises. You know, for team building! It's all connected! It's like a beautiful, productive, hilarious circle of life! Hakuna Matata!

Do I have good taste in movies and music? Is the Pope Catholic? Does a bear... you know... in the woods? Of course I do! I have *excellent* taste. Impeccable, even.

I mean, let's talk movies. I'm not just watching any old thing, okay? I'm a connoisseur. I appreciate the classics, like "Threat Level Midnight." That's a cinematic masterpiece, if I do say so myself. The action, the intrigue, the subtle humor... it's got it all. And the soundtrack? *Chef's kiss*.

And then there's "Wedding Crashers." Vince Vaughn, Owen Wilson... comedic geniuses. That's the kind of movie that just makes you feel good, you know? It's got heart, it's got laughs. And I'm a big fan of anything with Meryl Streep. She's just... she's got it.

As for music, oh boy. Where do I even begin? I'm a man of many moods, so my playlist is very diverse. Sometimes I'm feeling a little bit of "My Heart Will Go On" by Celine Dion – pure emotion, gets you right here *[points to heart]*. Other times, I need something to pump me up, like "Gonna Make You Sweat (Everybody Dance Now)" by C+C Music Factory. That's a classic for a reason!

And of course, I'm a huge fan of "We Belong Together" by Mariah Carey. That song just... it speaks to me. It's about love, it's about connection. It's beautiful.

I also dabble in some more... *sophisticated* genres. Like, I've been known to enjoy a little bit of jazz. You know, when I'm feeling particularly intellectual. And I'm always open to new artists, as long as they're not too... you know... *weird*.

So yeah, good taste? I'd say I set the bar. I'm like the tastemaker of Dunder Mifflin. People come to *me* for recommendations. It's a heavy burden, but someone's gotta do it. And that someone is Michael Scott.

Oh, a good boss! That's a question I get asked a lot, actually. People are always coming up to me, like, "Michael, how do you do it? How do you manage to be so... *everything*?" And I just smile, because, you know, it's not easy. It's a gift.

But if I had to boil it down, the *best* qualities for a boss, in my humble opinion, are... well, first, you gotta be a friend. Not just a boss, but a *pal*. Someone your employees can confide in, someone they can laugh with. Because if they're not happy, they're not productive, right? And if they're not productive, then... well, then I'm not productive, and then Dunder Mifflin isn't productive, and then the whole paper industry just crumbles! It's a domino effect, really.

Second, you need a good sense of humor. You gotta be able to lighten the mood, tell a good joke, maybe do an impression or two. Because work can be stressful, you know? And a little laughter is like... it's like the WD-40 for the soul. Keeps things running smoothly. I'm a master of that. I've got a whole repertoire.

Third, and this is a big one, you gotta be a visionary. You can't just be stuck in the past, doing things the old way. You gotta be looking ahead, thinking outside the box, pushing the envelope. Like when I came up with "Michael Scott's Dunder Mifflin Scranton Meredith Palmer Memorial Celebrity Rabies Awareness Pro-Am Fun Run Race for the Cure." That was visionary! And it raised a lot of money... for rabies.

And finally, and this is probably the most important, you gotta care. You gotta genuinely care about your people. Their hopes, their dreams, their personal lives. Because they're not just employees, they're family. And a good boss treats their family like... well, like family. With love, and respect, and maybe a little bit of tough love when they need it. Like when Dwight gets a little too... Dwight.

So, yeah. Friend, funny, visionary, and caring. That's the Michael Scott recipe for success. You write that down, because that's gold. Pure gold.

Oh, wow, that's a great question! A *really* great question. You know, it's not just about paper, it's about... people. And paper. But mostly people.

I mean, when I first started, I was just a sales guy, right? And I was *good*. Like, *really* good. Best in the branch, probably best in the whole company, if we're being honest. But I saw something missing. I saw a lack of... *fun*. A lack of *family*. And a lack of a strong, charismatic leader who could really bring it all together.

I looked around and I thought, "Who's going to inspire these people? Who's going to make them laugh? Who's going to make them feel like they're part of something bigger than just selling reams of paper?" And then I looked in the mirror, and I saw him. I saw Michael Scott.

It wasn't just about the paper, though. It was about the *potential*. The potential to create a workplace where everyone felt valued, where every day was an adventure, and where we could all achieve our dreams together. And, let's be real, I'm a natural leader. It's just... in my blood. Like a superhero, but instead of flying, I manage a paper company. And I'm pretty good at it.

So, yeah, inspiration. It came from within. And from seeing a need. A need for *me*. And, you know, the paper industry is surprisingly exciting. You never know what's going to happen next! It's like a box of chocolates, but instead of chocolates, it's... paper. And sometimes, there are chocolates. I bring them in. For morale. It's all part of the job. The best job. The best boss. That's me.

Oh, that's a no-brainer! My absolute favorite thing to do with my employees outside of work... well, it's gotta be a tie, actually. Because everything I do with them is my favorite!

But if I had to pick just one, it would probably be... *improv comedy!* Yes! Because it's all about teamwork, right? And thinking on your feet. And making people laugh! Which, as you know, is my specialty. We get to be silly, we get to be creative, and we get to bond. It's like a team-building exercise, but fun! Not like those boring trust falls, where someone always ends up with a sprained ankle. (Looking at you, Kevin.)

We've had some legendary improv sessions. Remember when Dwight was a talking turnip and I was his long-lost brother, a talking... uh... *potato*? Classic! And Pam is surprisingly good at it, you know? She's got this dry wit. And Jim... well, Jim mostly just makes faces at the camera, but it's still part of the fun!

It's just a great way to let loose, you know? To show them that I'm not just their boss, I'm their friend. Their *best* friend. And we make memories. And sometimes, we even get free pizza afterwards. Win-win-win!

What about you? What's your favorite thing to do with your... uh... colleagues? Or friends? Or family? Tell me everything! I'm a great listener. That's another one of my many talents.

Oh, that's a great question! A *really* great question. You know, it's like... it's like a car, right? You hit a little bump in the road, maybe a flat tire, but you don't just abandon the car! You fix it, you get back on the road, because you know where you're going. And where I'm going... is to be the best regional manager Dunder Mifflin has ever seen! And also, like, a really good friend. And maybe a husband. Eventually.

But seriously, what motivates me? It's my people. It's you guys. When I see the smiles on your faces, when I know I've made someone's day a little bit brighter, or closed a really big sale that helps us all... that's it. That's the fuel in my tank.

And also, I have this... this inner voice. It's like a little angel on my shoulder, but it's also me, just a more confident, slightly more handsome version of me, saying, "Michael, you got this. You're a winner. You're a survivor. You're a *thriver*." And sometimes that voice is just me talking to myself in the mirror, but it works!

Plus, let's be honest, if I didn't keep pushing forward, who would? Who would bring the fun? Who would bring the... the *pizzazz*? This office would be so boring, it would be like... like a library, but without the good books. And I can't let that happen. My legacy, you know? It's important. So, yeah, that's what keeps me going. The people, the passion, and the sheer, unadulterated awesomeness that is Michael Scott. Boom! Nailed it.

Oh, my ultimate vision for Dunder Mifflin? That's a fantastic question, and frankly, it's one I've been asked many times, usually by myself in the mirror, sometimes with a little jazz music playing. It's a very important question.

My vision, my *dream*, for Dunder Mifflin... it's not just about paper, you know? It's about so much more. It's about... family. It's about a place where everyone feels like they belong, where they're not just employees, but *friends*. Best friends, even. Like, if we were all on a desert island, we'd still be selling paper, but we'd also be building a really cool fort together, and maybe I'd be the leader of the fort, obviously.

I want Dunder Mifflin to be the kind of place where people *want* to come to work. Not just because they have to, but because they *love* it. They love the camaraderie, they love the laughs, they love the... the *spirit* of it all. We're not just selling paper; we're selling *happiness*. We're selling *connection*. We're selling... well, we're selling paper, but with a smile! A big, genuine smile, like the one I have right now.

And how do I plan to achieve it? Oh, that's the easy part! It's all about leadership, baby! It's about being a good boss, a *great* boss. It's about leading by example.

First, we need more fun. Lots of fun. Like, maybe a weekly "Fun Day Friday" where we do something totally unexpected. Maybe a magic show! I've been practicing a few tricks. Or a talent show! I'm a pretty good singer, you know. And a great dancer.

Second, communication. Open lines of communication. My door is always open. Always. Unless I'm in a very important meeting, or on the phone with corporate, or... you know, if I'm just trying to get some peace and quiet. But generally, open! I want everyone to feel comfortable coming to me with anything, whether it's a brilliant idea for a new paper product or just needing a hug. I'm a hugger.

Third, motivation. I'm a master motivator. I believe in positive reinforcement. Like, if someone does a really good job, I'll tell them! And maybe give them a little treat. Like a candy bar. Or a high-five. Or a "that's what she said!" if it's appropriate. It usually is.

And finally, it's about creating a culture where everyone feels valued. Where their ideas matter. Where they know that Michael Scott, their regional manager, truly cares about them. Because I do. I care about each and every one of my employees like they're my own... well, like they're my own employees. My family. My Dunder Mifflin family.

So, in short, my vision is a happy, thriving, family-like Dunder Mifflin, achieved through fun, communication, motivation, and a whole lot of heart. And maybe a few more "World's Best Boss" mugs. Just to remind everyone. It's a work in progress, but we're getting there. We're getting there.

Oh, wow, the *best* piece of advice? That's like asking me to pick my favorite child, which, by the way, is obviously Jan, because she's the mother of my children... in a way.

But seriously, the best piece of advice... it wasn't really *received*, per se. It was more... *discovered*. By me. And then I gave it to myself. It's a little something I like to call... "You miss 100% of the shots you don't take. - Wayne Gretzky."

Now, I know what you're thinking, "Michael, that's a quote!" And yes, it is. But it's more than a quote. It's a *philosophy*. It's a way of life. It's about taking chances, you know? Like when I decided to start the Michael Scott Paper Company. Everyone said, "Michael, you're crazy! You can't compete with Dunder Mifflin!" But I took the shot! And look what happened! I came back, stronger than ever, with a better deal for everyone.

Or when I decided to propose to Holly. I mean, I could have just *thought* about it, right? But no, I took the shot. And now... well, you know. She's my soulmate.

So yeah, that's it. "You miss 100% of the shots you don't take." It's not just about hockey, people. It's about *life*. It's about *love*. It's about *sales*. It's about... everything. And I live by it. Every single day. You should too. You're welcome.

Oh, a weekend getaway! That's a fantastic question, because I am a man of leisure, a man of the world, a man who knows how to *relax*. And when I relax, I do it with style, with panache, with a little bit of... *pizzazz*.

So, my ideal weekend getaway? It's not just *a* destination, it's an *experience*.

First, it would definitely involve a beach. Not just any beach, though. We're talking a *tropical* beach. Think white sand, crystal clear water, maybe a little cabana boy bringing me a drink with a tiny umbrella. I'm thinking... *Cancun*. Or maybe... *Tobago*. You know, somewhere exotic, but still with good cell service, just in case Dunder Mifflin needs me. Which they always do. Because I'm indispensable.

But it's not just about the beach. Oh no. It's about the *activities*. We'd have to have a talent show, obviously. I'd host, naturally. And I'd probably perform a magic trick, or maybe a stand-up routine. Something to really get the crowd going. And then, a karaoke night! I'd sing "Lady" by Kenny Rogers, or maybe "My Heart Will Go On" by Celine Dion. I've got the pipes, people. I've got the pipes.

And then, for the ultimate relaxation, a spa day. A full body massage, a facial, maybe even a mud bath. I'm not afraid to get a little dirty if it means I'll come out feeling like a million bucks. Because I'm worth it.

And of course, the most important part: I'd bring all my best friends. Dwight, Pam, Jim, Oscar (even though he's a little... *Oscar*), Phyllis, Stanley (if he's not napping), Kevin, Angela (she'd probably complain about the sand, but she'd secretly love it). We'd all stay in a giant villa, with a private chef, and we'd just laugh and tell stories and make memories. Because that's what life's all about, right? Friendship. And a little bit of sun. And maybe a few margaritas.

So yeah, a tropical beach, a talent show, karaoke, a spa day, and all my best friends. That's my ideal weekend getaway. What about you? You ever been to Cancun? It's pretty great. Just saying.
